title.narrative: Mitigation and resilience to 2021 drought´s impact to agriculture livelihoods from small farmers in southern Angola

description.narrative: The main aim of this FAO project is to mitigate the 2021 drought's impact on agricultural livelihoods from small farmers in Cunene, Huila, and Huambo by ensuring Climate-Smart Agriculture-related inputs, technologies, and knowledge. The latter will directly contribute to food security since it will mitigate harvest losses by facilitating access to basic ad-hoc irrigation technologies. It will also trigger production and productivity by securing adequate and diverse seeds, tools, and ploughs for animal traction. And finally, it will protect the household's assets, namely animals, which are at risk due to transhumance movements. FAO will undertake activities i) facilitating access and management capacities of irrigation kits and pedal bike pumps, ii) To timely distribute seeds according to local production culture, also allowing production diversification and increase of food supply both for beneficiaries' families and communities, iii) To engage Field Farms Schools in advance development cycles as suppliers of inputs necessary in this context, concretely sweet potato and cassava seeds, iv) To improve animal nutrition management by resorting to Field Farm Schools facilitators as Community-Based Animal Health Workers C-B AHW, with the abilities to provide technical assistance to surrounding farmers, and v) To reinforce the immunity of animals for agriculture work by providing veterinary kits specifically in Huambo, supported by adequate technical overseeing in coordination with the Institute of Veterinary Services (ISV). . In total, 12,350 persons will benefit, including 1,735 women and 7,625 girls. FAO also expects 2,956 people with disabilities to be among those targeted
